content:
• Wednesday, August 14, 2013

  • Nikkei lower, Japan says deflation ending

    • The Nikkei falls 1.6% in Tokyo as the yen is 0.34% firmer against the dollar to ¥97.80. In its monthly economic report, the Japanese government kept its assessment of the overall economy largely unchanged while noting that "recent price developments indicate deflation is ending."
    • Across the region: Hang Seng +0.5%, Shanghai Composite +0.2%, ASX +0.1%, Kospi closed.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:52 PM
  • LNVGY

    Lenovo posts larger-than-expected net profit

    • Lenovo (OTCPK:LNVGY) — now the world's largest PC maker — posts an FQ1 net profit of $174M (+23% Y/Y), beating consensus estimates by $8M.
    • Revenue for the period comes in at $8.78B, up 10% Y/Y.
    • Gross margin and operating margin were 13.6% and 2.3% respectively for Q1. (presentation)
    • Shares +2.9% in Hong Kong trade.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:35 PM
  • PT-OLD

    Portugal Telecom sells off on Q2 results, dividend cut

    • Portugal Telecom shares (PT-OLD -7.9%) fell hard after releasing Q2 results.
    • EPS of €0.28 was up 257% Y/Y, on the back of a €310M one-time gain on the sale of PT's stake in a Macau carrier (positive EPS impact of €0.34). However, revenue fell 5.5% Y/Y to €1.54B. The Portuguese business' revenue fell 4.4% Y/Y to €645.5M, and revenue from indirectly-owned Brazilian telco Oi fell 7.9% Y/Y to €694.4M due to devaluation of the real.
    • EBITDA fell 7.9% Y/Y to €277.6M. FCF turned positive to €170.4M from -€200.4M in Q2 2012, thanks to the CTM stake sale.
    • The company also guillotined its dividend as it attempts to manage €4.6B in debt with minimal cash flows. The dividend will be €0.10 per annum in 2013 and 2014 (implied forward yield of 3.3%), down from €0.325 in 2012. (6-F), (presentation)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:25 PM
  • VLTC

    Voltari falls after Q2 results, completes business re-orientation

    • Voltari (OTC:VLTC -3.9%) takes a dive after releasing Q2 results.
    • On July 30, the company finished the unwinding of its U.S. carrier hosting business and will be solely focused on its mobile media business going forward. The company will retain $332.6M in NOLs expiring between 2019-2032 from its discontinued carrier operations.
    • As of Aug. 12, Carl Icahn owned 30.4% of outstanding common stock, 95.5% of all series J preferred stock (current  redemption value of $33M, including 13% PIK annual dividends to-date of $2.9M), and $20M in 10% debt maturing Aug. 2013.
    • The company's mobile media operations are comprised of Voltari Media and Enterprise. Whereas Voltari broke out the units in Q1, it did not in Q2. It's likely the enterprise segment continues to decline, with most of the decline made up by growth in the Voltari Media business. SA contributor Paulo Santos made a case for the company back in July.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:02 PM
  • FU

    More on FAB Universal Q2 results

    • FAB Universal (FU +5.8%) closed up after releasing Q2 results in the morning. Revenue grew 14.6% Q/Q to $25.9M.   (PR)
    • The company reiterated full-year guidance for revenue of $98.9M-$102.6M and net income of $19.3M-$20.1M.
    • Revenue for the digital business (including Intelligent Kiosk operations) grew 41% Q/Q to $9.6M as FAB added nearly 2K kiosks to bring its total installed base to 16K. Gross profit outpaced top-line growth, up 47% Q/Q.
    • CEO Chris Spencer on Fab's growth strategy: "First, push hard to build out our network and strengthen our infrastructure. Second, increase the quantity and variety of digital content that we offer through the kiosk network. Third, ... drive membership growth and advertising revenue." (CC)
     
     
     
     
    | 8:25 PM
  • GAME

    Shanda Games rebounds on strong Tencent numbers

    • Shanda Games (GAME +10.8%) rallied strongly after competitor Tencent (OTCPK:TCEHY) announced gaming revenue grew 31% Y/Y in Q2 to 7.5B yuan.
    • With today's move, Shanda recovered some of the losses stemming from its questionable affiliate acquisitions on July 29.
    • The stock remains down 29% since the announcement.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:04 PM
  • RENN

    Renren EPS beats, revenue misses, guidance light; shares plunge

    • Renren (NYSE:RENN): Q2 EPS of -$0.03 beats by $0.04.
    • Revenue of $49.6M (+10.7% Y/Y) misses by $5.5M.
    • 8.9M shares repurchased.
    • Q3 revenue guidance of $47M-$49M (-3% to -7% Y/Y), well below $64.6M consensus.
    • Shares -11% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:31 PM
  • NOK

    For whom Cisco tolls: Nasdaq futures, networking stocks down AH

    • Nasdaq-100 futures (QQQ, XLK) -0.5% AH after Cisco provides relatively light FQ1 guidance to go with an FQ4 beat, and also reports Asia-Pac/Japan orders were down 3% Y/Y (macro is blamed).
    • Networking/telecom hardware vendors and some of their suppliers are naturally the biggest decliners. Many of them have run up strongly this year on hopes of gradually improving carrier capex and enterprise IT spending. ALU -3.3% AH. JNPR -2.4%. ARUN -1.4%. FFIV -2%. ARRS -2.4%. RVBD -3.2%. JDSU -1.6%. FNSR -2.8%. CIEN -2.2%. CAVM -2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:07 PM | 1 Comment
  • CYCC

    More on Cyclacel Pharmaceuticals earnings

    • Cyclacel Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:CYCC) Q2 slips on a per share basis as losses come in higher than anticipated.
    • Q2 EPS of ($0.10), versus ($0.45) reported last year.
    • Total revenue of $264K compared to $26K in prior year.
    • R&D expenses were $2.6M compared to $1.7M for the same period in 2012, primarily due to clinical trial and manufacturing costs.
    • Cash and cash equivalents totaled $33.7M.
    • Shares -4.4% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:56 PM
  • A

    Agilent +3.2% AH following FQ3 beat; FQ4 revenue guidance light

    • Agilent (NYSE:A) expects FQ4 revenue of $1.7B-$1.72B and EPS of $0.75-$0.77 vs. a consensus of $1.73B and $0.76. It's worth noting Agilent also issued light revenue guidance in May (to go with light EPS guidance), but nonetheless traded higher the next day.
    • FQ3 orders -4% Y/Y, better than FQ2's -8% and even with rev. growth. Electronic Measurement orders -17% (wireless manufacturing still weak), a smaller drop than FQ2's -27%. Chemical Analysis orders +2% Y/Y vs. flat in FQ2. Life Sciences +1% (unchanged), Diagnostics & Genomics an acquisition-boosted +51%.
    • Book-to-bill was 0.97. R&D spend +6% Y/Y to $171M, SG&A -4% to $449M (job cuts).
    • Electronic Measurement revenue -17%, Life Sciences +3%, Chemical Analysis +1%, Diagnostics & Genomics +54% (thanks to Dako acquisition) .
    • FQ3 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 6:52 PM
  • WPM

    More on Silver Wheaton's Q2 results, reports record production

    • More on Silver Wheaton's (SLW) Q2 results: Reports record attributable silver equivalent production of 8.6M oz. (6.4M oz. of silver and 35.6K oz. of gold), up 28% Y/Y from 6.7M oz. in the year-ago quarter.
    • Silver equivalent sales of 7.2M oz. (5.1M oz. of silver and 33.9K oz. of gold), up 4% from 6.9M oz. in the year-ago quarter.
    • Average cash costs were $4.14 per silver oz., $391 per gold oz.; on a silver equivalent basis, average cash costs rose to $4.77 vs. $4.06 a year ago due primarily to an increase in the percentage of revenue from gold sales.
    • Shares -1.5% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM | 1 Comment

  • After-hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: MCO +5%. DDS +5%. DANG +5%. SIGM +5%. OLED +4%.
    • Top losers: VIPS -10%. CSCO -9%. MPW -5%. NTAP -4%. TASR -3%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:34 PM
  • MPW

    Medical Properties Trust sinks after announcing public offering

    • Medical Properties Trust (NYSE:MPW) falls 4.9% AH as the company announces plans to offer 10M shares and $150M in senior notes due 2022 (that makes $350M in outstanding 2022 senior notes).
    • MPW will use the proceeds to fund the acquisition of three general acute care hospitals. (PR)
    • For the bull thesis, see SA Pro contributor Dane Bowler's recent article.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:23 PM
  • VIPS

    Vipshop down AH on weak Q3 guidance

    • Vipshop's (NYSE:VIPS) Q3 revenue guidance of $365M-$370M is below expectations of $376M. Shares are down 10.8% AH.
    • In Q2, VIPS beat consensus and its own guidance for the 4th straight quarter.
    • Gross profit outpaced revenue growth (+160% Y/Y), rising 179.6% to $82.6M.
    • Opex grew 118.6% to $77.3M. Fulfillment expenses were up 108.4% to $42.8M, marketing up 128.9% to $15.1M, technology/content up 225.9% to $8.7M, and G&A up 92.9% to $10.8M.
    • Vipshop reports active customers in Q2 increased 138.7% Y/Y to 3.5M. Total order growth was similar, up 136.3% to 11M.
    • The strong order and active customer numbers arrive a day after Macquarie's Internet Traffic Tracker report indicated June traffic to Vipshop's site was down 20% M/M (the report sent the stock tumbling 6.8% yesterday).
    • Q2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:20 PM
  • DF

    Dean Foods announces 1-2 reverse stock split

    • Dean Foods (NYSE:DF) announces a 1-for-2 reverse stock split in an effort to boost the dairy giant's share price.
    • Earnings have suffered as the company has been pressured by higher raw milk prices and increased competition.
    • The split will reduce the float to around 94.3M shares from about 188.5M, and should be effective after the close of trading on August 26.
    • Shares +1.4% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:12 PM
  • WPM

    Silver Wheaton misses by $0.05, misses on revenues

    • Silver Wheaton (SLW): Q2 EPS of $0.20 misses by $0.05.
    • Revenue of $166.9M (-1.7% Y/Y) misses by $21.91M. Shares -1.2% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:09 PM
  • CSCO

    Cisco issues light guidance, cutting 4K jobs; shares now -10.3% AH

    • Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) guides on its FQ4 CC for 3%-5% Y/Y FQ1 revenue growth, and FQ1 EPS of $0.50-$0.51. That's somewhat unfavorable to a consensus for 4.9% Y/Y rev. growth and EPS of $0.51.
    • Total orders rose 4% Y/Y in FQ4, less than rev. growth of 6%. Americas orders +5% and EMEA +6%, but Asia-Pac/Japan -3%, thanks in part to a 6% drop for China. Cisco says it's seeing an "improving" but nonetheless "mixed" macro environment.
    • The company also announces it's cutting 4K jobs (5.5% of its workforce), and expects to record $550M in pre-tax charges related to the move.
    • FQ4 results, details
     
     
     
     
    | 5:07 PM | 3 Comments
  • VTNR

    Vertex Energy beats by $0.05

    • Vertex Energy (NASDAQ:VTNR): Q2 EPS of $0.10 beats by $0.05.
    • Revenue of $35.1M (+12% Y/Y) beats by $0.09M. Shares +6.2% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:58 PM
  • JCP

    J.C. Penney jumps after reporter says August SSS tracking positive

    • J.C. Penney (NYSE:JCP) surged in the final hour of trading to close nearly 4% higher.
    • Apparently, the move comes courtesy of a twitter message from a NY Post reporter (original tweet) who said sources indicate same-store sales are "tracking positive" for August. 
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 3 Comments
  • NTAP

    NetApp now -4% AH; revenue guidance midpoint below consensus

    • NetApp (NASDAQ:NTAP) expects FQ2 revenue of $1.56B-$1.66B and EPS of $0.60-$0.65 vs. a consensus of $1.63B and $0.63.
    • The revenue guidance midpoint ($1.61B) is slightly below consensus. CEO Tom Georgens mentions seeing "an uneven macro environment."
    • Expectations had risen thanks to a spring/summer run-up, fueled in part by bullish analyst commentary.
    • $849.5M was spent on buybacks (helped drive EPS beat). Exc. restructuring charges, opex -1% Y/Y vs. rev. growth of 5%.
    • CC at 5:30PM ET. FQ1 results, PR.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:15 PM
  • CSCO

    Cisco Systems beats by $0.01, beats on revenue

    • Cisco Systems (NASDAQ:CSCO): FQ4 EPS of $0.52 beats by $0.01.
    • Revenue of $12.42B (+6% Y/Y) beats by $0.02B. Shares -2.2% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:06 PM | 4 Comments
  • AMD

    AMD, Nvidia close higher after Jon Peddie numbers released

    • GPU archrivals AMD (AMD +3.4%) and Nvidia (NVDA +4.3%) close higher on a moderately down day for tech. The release of Jon Peddie's Q2 GPU figures could be a factor.
    • The research firm estimates GPU shipments rose 4.6% Q/Q in Q2 even as PC shipments fell 2.5%. This is attributed to growing consumer interest in "double-attach" systems featuring both a discrete GPU and a CPU with an on-board GPU (most of Intel and AMD's latest CPUs have one).
    • Integrated GPUs have been taking share from discrete GPUs for a long time. Thus, any favorable data regarding discrete demand is likely to be well-received.
    • Counting integrated GPUs, Intel (INTC +0.2%) is estimated to have a 62% GPU share in Q2, up from 61.1% in Q1 and unchanged Y/Y. AMD is given a 21.9% share, up from Q1's 20.6% but down from 22.7% a year ago. Nvidia is assigned a 16.1% share, down from 18.3% in Q1 but up from 14.8% a year ago.
    • Nvidia recently released July quarter figures that pointed to Y/Y share gains.
    • Also: In what could prove a positive for AMD, Digitimes reports game console chip orders for September and October have already come in, and that orders are expected to stay strong November/December. Much, of course, depends on how consumers respond to the actual PS4 and Xbox One launches.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:04 PM | 4 Comments
  • NTAP

    NetApp beats by $0.04, misses on revenues

    • NetApp (NASDAQ:NTAP): FQ1 EPS of $0.53 beats by $0.04.
    • Revenue of $1.52B (+5% Y/Y) misses by $0.01B. Shares -1.8% AH. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:02 PM
  • BIOL

    Biolase pummeled on solvency concerns; reduces S-3 registration from $30M to $5M

    • Biolase (BIOL -33%) gets hammered on solvency concerns after saying that it's reducing its registration statement from $30M to $5M due to an unwarranted amount of confusion in the marketplace since filing its S-3 on July 26.
    • The announcement comes just after Comerica Bank (NYSE:CMA) agrees to waive its requirement that BIOL earn at least $500K EBITDA.
    • BIOL reported a net loss of $2.6M (EBITDA) for Q2 2013.
    • Under the terms of the waiver, the two companies agreed on a further amendment to the loan agreement containing revised financial covenants by September 13.
    • They also agree that until Sept 13, BIOL cannot extend its loan facility by more than $7.5M.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM
  • CPB

    Consumer sues Campbell Soup, AHA over Heart-Check Mark logo

    • Kerry O’Shea of Huntington Beach, California is angry with Campbell Soup (CPB -1.8%) and the American Heart Association — so angry in fact, that she's filing a lawsuit.
    • O'Shea claims that the AHA has no business allowing CPB to display the "Heart-Check Mark" logo on the side of Healthy Request soups because each can allegedly has "at least six times as much sodium as the organization recommends."
    • "That misrepresentation (or omission of the true facts) is unfair, deceptive, and misleading," Bloomberg quotes the complaint as saying.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM | 1 Comment
  • MTP

    Dara BioSciences slides on higher Q2 net losses

    • Dara BioSciences (DARA -2.5%) dips after posting a higher Q2 net loss.
    • The increase in loss was primarily a result of costs from establishing a sales and marketing, distribution and regulatory infrastructure to support the company's oncology products.
    • As of June 30, 2013 cash and cash equivalents totaled $4,490,899.
    • DARA says it believes it is well-positioned with current funds available along with 2013 projected sales to fund planned operations and meet its obligations through the end of the year.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:36 PM
  • RIO

    Rio Tinto lays off nearly 2,000 Oyu Tolgoi workers amid dispute

    • Nearly 2,000 workers at Rio Tinto's (RIO +0.7%) Oyu Tolgoi copper and gold mine in Mongolia reportedly have been laid off amid a financing dispute.
    • The layoff comes after months of disagreement between the government and Rio over how to share revenue from the mine.
    • On Aug. 12, Rio's Turquoise Hill (TRQ -2%) unit, which owns 66% of the mine, said funding and development of the mine’s underground expansion would be delayed until "matters can be resolved with the Mongolian government and a new timetable has been agreed."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:29 PM | 4 Comments
  • CRV

    Coast Distribution System jumps after earnings

    • Coast Distribution System Inc. (CRV +14%) soars after posting Q2 results.
    • Q2 EPS of $0.23 was more than double Q2 2012's $0.11/ share.
    • Revenue for the period rose 4.3% Y/Y to $35.6M. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:25 PM
  • MNKD

    Analysts weigh in on MannKind following Afrezza results

    • Calls and commentary are coming in now regarding the Afrezza Affinity trial results released this morning by MannKind (MNKD +11.5%).
    • "We assume that the FDA should approve Afrezza the third time around," Cowen's Simos Simeonidis says, adding that the focus has now shifted to whether the company can find a partner.
    • On that note, Griffin Securities' Kieth Markey thinks "a deal could be struck fairly quickly, as the regulatory risk has virtually dissipated." Markey sees FDA approval in April 2014.
    • JMP downgrades the shares to Market Perform from Market Outperform perhaps because the most obvious near-term catalyst is passed.
    • Previous coverage
     
     
     
     
    | 3:19 PM
  • SKBI

    Skystar Pharmaceutical rockets higher on Q2 report

    • Skystar Bio Pharmaceutical (SKBI +54%) soars on a solid Q2 report.
    • Q2 EPS was $0.49 versus $0.23 in the year ago period.
    • Revenue came in at $11.3M, +27.4% Y/Y.
    • Revenue breakdown: Micro-organism products $4M, +0.7% Y/Y; Veterinary medicines $6.3M, +155.9% Y/Y; Feed additives $500K, -59.4% Y/Y; Veterinary vaccines $500K, -56.5% Y/Y.
    • Gross margin for the period was 52.6% compared to 57.8%, slipping due to the majority of revenue coming from less profitable veterinary medications as it resumes veterinary medication production at its Huxian facility.
    • The company reaffirms 2013 guidance to be in the range of $40M - $45M for the full year.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:17 PM
  • GPOR

    Gulfport Energy upgraded at Stifel, sees next leg up in the next 6-9 months

    • Gulfport Energy (GPOR +2.4%) is upgraded to Buy from Hold with a $73 target price at Stifel Nicolaus, which sees last week's 9% drop in the stock when GPOR lowered its 2013 production guidance by 30% as a good entry point to build or add to positions.
    • The firm believes the upcoming acceleration in quarterly production volumes and the possible release of 2014 guidance with Q3 results will be the two key drivers that could cause the next leg up in the stock in the coming 6-9 months.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:14 PM
  • AAXN

    Taser's AXON technology gains traction

    • Shares of Taser (TASR +5.6%) get a jolt after the company announces new orders for its AXON flex, on-officer cameras and EVIDENCE.com service by the Fort Worth Police Department and the Dallas/ Fort Worth International Airport Department of Public Safety.
    • The company will recognize hardware revenue from the orders in Q3, while revenue from the EVIDENCE.com deal will be recognized over the service period. (PR)
    • Other AXON news from today: The Surprise, Arizona Police Department will issue the on-officer cameras (and EVIDENCE.com service) to all patrol officers.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:00 PM | 1 Comment
  • FANG

    Diamondback Energy slips on 4M share stock offering

    • Diamondback Energy (FANG -3.7%) slips today after announcing a 4M share public offering, subject to market and other conditions.
    • The underwriters will also have an option to purchase up to an additional 600K shares of common stock.
    • The company intends to use the net proceeds to fund its pending acquisitions of additional acreage in the Permian Basin, and to use any remaining net proceeds to fund a portion of its exploration and development activities.
    • Credit Suisse is the sole book runner.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:58 PM
  • ELOS

    Cantor says Syneron Medical in position for a better H2

    • Cantor Fitzgerald weighs in on Syneron Medical (ELOS -4.8%) disappointing Q2, saying the company is poised for a better second half.
    • The firm notes that PAD sales were slightly weaker than expected on further non-core weakness in the U.S. and FX headwinds, but EBU posted stellar growth, due in part to the QVC events.
    • They remain bullish long-term despite management changes and uneven results, but it believes that the pieces are in place for consistent and sustainable growth going forward.
    • It maintains its $16 price target on the shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:45 PM
  • ZEP

    Zep Inc. moves higher on cost-cutting, guidance update

    • Armor All maker Zep Inc. (ZEP +3%) zips higher after updating investors on the progress of its "complexity-reduction activities."
    • The company's non-sales workforce will be reduced by ~6% (80-100 positions).
    • Annualized cost savings should come in at the high end of previous guidance ($8-12M).
    • ZEP sees $9M of recorded cost-savings in FY14.
    • Cost cuts will come through mostly in SG&A expense although a fourth will be reflected in COGS.
    • Updated FY13 revenue guidance: $685-690M versus consensus of $679.9M. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:33 PM
  • BIOS

    BioScrip prices upsized secondary offering

    • BioScrip (BIOS -5.2%) slips after pricing an upsized secondary offering of 6,895,873 shares.
    • The offering was originally at 6.8 million shares.
    • Underwriters also received options to buy up to 1M additional shares.
    • The offering is expected to close on or about August 19.
    • Morgan Stanley is acting as the sole underwriter of the offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:29 PM
  • ZAZA

    ZaZa Energy -30% after quarterly loss widens, revenue tumbles

    • ZaZa Energy (OTC:ZAZA -30.9%) shares swoon after the company reports a Q2 loss of $0.57 vs. a $0.49 loss in the year-ago quarter; revenues fell 23% Y/Y to $2.4M.
    • ZAZA attributes the revenue drop on the loss of $2.5M in Cotulla revenues as a result of the division of assets from a former joint venture.
    • Overall, oil and gas production fell 25% Y/Y to 30.305 boe.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:27 PM
  • CGIX

    Cancer Genetics falls after secondary

    • Cancer Genetics (CGIX -14.4%) plummets after pricing a 1.5M share public offering at $10, a 10% discount to Tuesday's close. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:18 PM
  • NLST

    Netlist turns positive in spite of Q2 miss

    • After trading lower this morning in response to its Q2 miss, Netlist (OTC:NLST +1.4%) is now slightly higher. The DRAM/NAND module maker's revenue fell 52% Y/Y to $5.1M as its primary product, NVvault, saw dwindling sales to Dell.
    • At the trough of its product cycle, Netlist saw gross margin collapse to 5% in Q2 from 26% in Q2 2012 thanks to sliding revenue and the effects of fixed costs. (10Q) (PR)
    • Nonetheless, net loss fell to $2.86M ($3.98M in Q2 2012) thanks to major R&D and SG&A spending cuts. In addition to manufacturing, Netlist has shifted operations such as "test engineering, sales, and financial administrative support" to its low-cost Chinese facilities.
    • Netlist expects sales to rebound as it ramps production of its new 32GB HyperCloud memory module, which was qualified for use with H-P's ProLiant DL380p Gen8 (currently the top-selling server in the world). The company claims its offering is 78% faster than rival memory technologies featuring a similar density.
    • Netlist expects HyperCloud sales to kick in at the end of 2013, and act as its primary growth driver over the next several years.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:13 PM
  • TNXP

    Tonix Pharmaceuticals closes it public offering

    • Tonix Pharmaceuticals Holding (TNXP -2.3%) slips after announcing the closing of its 2.6M share public offering of $4.25 per unit, with each unit consisting of one share of common stock and one warrant to purchase one share of common stock.
    • The company expects to use net proceeds from this offering to fund the clinical development of TNX-102 SL, for which a Phase 2b/3 clinical trial for the treatment of fibromyalgia is in process to begin in the Q313.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:52 PM
  • GRH

    GreenHunter Resources +8% on approval of waste fluid recycle/reuse facility

    • GreenHunter Resources (GRH +8%) says its site plan for the water recycling and barging facility located in Wheeling, W. Va., has been approved by the local planning commission.
    • The approval clears a major hurdle toward planned construction of a waste fluid recycle and reuse facility to serve the Utica and Marcellus shale regions.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:47 PM
  • NXGN

    Quality Systems slips on a less-than-stellar initiation at KeyBanc

    • Quality Systems (QSII -3.8%), slips on a tepid initiation at KeyBanc with an Underweight and a price target of $19 a share, saying that 2014 revenue growth will fall short of expectations.
    • The firm says QSII is facing a more saturated market for its core software offerings.
    • It's also dealing with increasing downstream competition from larger enterprise vendors such as Cerner and Epic Systems, who are continuing to acquire QSII’s physician practice customers and integrate them onto their enterprise.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:45 PM
  • VIAV

    JDS Uniphase slips following revenue miss, light guidance

    • In addition to missing FQ4 revenue estimates, JDS Uniphase (JDSU -2.5%) has guided for FQ1 revenue of $410M-$430M, below a $432.8M consensus.
    • Investors are disappointed, but only moderately so. A likely reason: JDS also disclosed on the CC its book-to-bill was above 1 for all business segments, and "well above 1 for ... network-related businesses."
    • The revenue miss is blamed on soft telecom demand, and the guidance on EMEA and Chinese weakness.
    • Test/measurement sales -3.3% Y/Y in FQ4 vs. -2% in FQ3. Optical components -1.5% vs. +3.5%. Optical security/performance (security pigments, gesture recognition) -6.8% vs. -1% (parts of the business are being wound down).
    • Gross margin was 45.3%, +20 bps Q/Q and +80 bps Y/Y. Op. margin was 7.2%, +40 bps Q/Q but -160 bps Y/Y.
    • Test/measurement sales are expected to fall 5%-10% Q/Q, optical components to rise 5%-10%, and security/performance to rise 2%-8%.
    • Ethernet-related sales were an area of strength (+37% Q/Q in FQ4). Rival Finisar is also seeing strong datacom sales. 100G sales were also strong.

  • CMRX

    Chimerix anti-infection drug falls short in Phase II

    • Chimerix's (CMRX, -3.3%) CMX001 preemptive therapy for adenovirus (AdV) infection failed to achieve statistical significance in a Phase II trial of recipients of blood or bone marrow from donors.
    • However, Chimerix says that encouraging results from the first proof-of-concept study for adenovirus infection support the continued clinical development of CMX001.
    • AdV causes respiratory infections such as the common cold in healthy individuals. In patients with weakened immune systems, such as those who have recently received bone marrow or organ transplants, AdV infections have a high mortality rate. (PR)
     
     
     
     
    | 9:09 AM
